I think I have figured out one reason. BTW I think purring can help humans as well. STORY TIME: I was working out and went into sauna afterwards. My watch told me that my heart rate was high with little to no activity, cause I was in sauna. Anyhow I tried deep breathing and laying down to no avail. My heart rate was still in the 130 range. I tried breathing again but this time I low hummed (purred) while breathing. Within a couple of minutes my heart rate dropped to 105 and continued to slow down. I felt a soothing rumble in my chest and could imagine my heart being soothed by the vibrations. THEORY: Cats purr to calm their active hearts.

Cats:
The cat (Felis catus) is a small carnivorous mammal It is the only domesticated species in the family Felidae and often referred to as the domestic cat to distinguish it from wild members of the family. The cat is either a house cat, a farm cat or a feral cat; the latter ranges freely and avoids human contact. Domestic cats are valued by humans for companionship and for their ability to hunt rodents. About 60 cat breeds are recognized by various cat registries.


The cat is similar in anatomy to the other felid species, has a strong flexible body, quick reflexes, sharp teeth and retractable claws adapted to killing small prey. Its night vision and sense of smell are well developed. Cat communication includes vocalizations like meowing, purring, trilling, hissing, growling and grunting as well as cat-specific body language. It is a solitary hunter, but a social species. It can hear sounds too faint or too high in frequency for human ears, such as those made by mice and other small mammals. It is a predator that is most active at dawn and dusk. It secretes and perceives pheromones.



Female domestic cats can have kittens from spring to late autumn, with litter sizes ranging from two to five kittens. Domestic cats are bred and shown as registered pedigreed cats, a hobby known as cat fancy. Failure to control the breeding of pet cats by spaying and neutering, as well as the abandonment of pets, resulted in large numbers of feral cats worldwide, contributing to the extinction of entire bird species, and evoking population control.



It was long thought that cat domestication was initiated in Egypt because cats in ancient Egypt were venerated since around 3100 BC. However, the earliest indication for the taming of an African wildcat (F. lybica) was found in Cyprus, where a cat skeleton was excavated close by a human Neolithic grave dating to around 7500 BC. African wildcats were probably first domesticated in the Near East.



As of 2017, the domestic cat was the second-most popular pet in the United States by number of pets owned, after freshwater fish, with 95 million cats owned. In the United Kingdom, around 7.3 million cats lived in more than 4.8 million households as of 2019.

I have heard that lions evolved from leopards and that leopards are also 1 of the domestic cat's ancestors.

I think I know why leopards are 1 of the domestic cat's ancestors. They can climb really well and so can domestic cats but not only that but leopards are 1 of the only wild cats that live so close to humans. Even a pride of lions would think twice about living near humans since they are afraid they will be shot.

But why did lions evolve from leopards? I mean yes some leopards are very muscular for their size and some leopards are more social than others but mutations in leopard genes causing a dramatic increase in muscle mass and socializing in a relatively short period of time seems almost impossible. Even if in areas with bigger prey more social and muscular leopards were selected I still don't see how leopards could go from being light and nimble and relatively unsocial to heavy and extremely social.

When a person stretches a joint to crack his knuckles, he creates negative pressure within the capsule. That vacuum allows more dissolved gas to enter the capsule as a bubble. When the gas bubble bursts, you hear the characteristic popping sound. The reason you can't re-crack your knuckles immediately is that the joint needs more gas first. Although cracking your joints will not lead to arthritis, overzealous cracking can injure the ligaments that support those joints. This results in a mild pa

Technically it isnt and is (in which it is neither).Joints are covered with a capsule. A special type of liquid called synovial fluid is contained within the capsule. Synovial fluid acts as a lubricant and contains nutrients for the cartilage and bone. The synovial fluid also contains dissolved gas.

Yes. Because we only have three color rods in our eyes. Green, Blue, and Red. While a dog only has Green and Blue. So they cannot see our colors as well. A Mantis shrimp has 16 color rods in it's cornea making it able to see many many many more colors than we can. Though we can never experience those colors. It is impossible because we do not have the same visual eyesight or as many color rods as other animals. So yes. There are colors that we will never ever see in our entire human race :-(

Small, slow wags of the tail say the dog is questioning things around the environment it is in. Either it is not sure whether it is the target dog or the person around it is friendly, or it is not sure what is going on or what is expected of it to do. Large, fast wags of the tail may be a sign of a happy, excited, or an energetic dog, but can also signal aggression.

When the tail is held high, it shows that the dog is alert and aware; the tail between the legs means that the dog is afraid or frightened. If the fur on the tail is also bristled, the dog is saying it is willing to defend itself or pups.

It is unknown for certain why cats purr, but the following reasons are speculated:

Cats often purr when being petted, becoming relaxed, or when eating. Female cats are known to sometimes purr while giving birth. The anticipated purr has a high-frequency component not ordinarily present. However, this variety of purring seems to be found only in cats in a one-on-one relationship with their caretakers. This "soliciting purr" is different from a cat's normal purring.

Yes. It's one of the most common things in the whole 'sleep and dreaming' world. It is refered to as "Hypnic Jerk" which results during the transition to Rapid Eye Movement or REM stage of sleep. It's the point where your body relaxes its muscles and a feeling of weightlessness occurs. It sometimes happens when you are still aware of your senses, the sensation scares you so you 'jerk' awake. It's caused by sleep deprivation, fatigue, sleep anxiety, or discomfort.

............still lucid (conscious and aware of what is happening around you).  This is very common and can only become a problem if it worsens.  If it does worsen, then you may eventually experience sleep paralysis.  This is where you are completely awake in your head, but your body is asleep.  Basically, sleep paralysis is HARMLESS, but can be a scary experience.  
Search around and you could find just exactly what you're experiencing.

1/2
A lot is known about sensations like that while about to sleep/waking up.  It's completely harmless (99% of the time) and the only thing you should be worried about is that it could be a symptom for an underlying sleep disorder. (But it's very unlikely you do have a sleep disorder if that's the only unusual thing you are experiencing during sleep) 
My bet is that you fall asleep differently than other people.  It could very likely be caused by your body falling asleep while you are........

It is simple....When light from a camera hits the retina of the person's eye, the light bounces from it and into the CMOS sensor on the camera. The retina actually is red, so the camera is just picking up the real color. When we look into another person's eye, the light bouncing back from it gets absorbed into our eyes, which tells our brain that the center of their eyes are black.
